newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: FOCUS - Portugal inflation firmly on track for EMU.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Portugal inflation firmly on track for EMU.

text.p: Portugal's inflation fell in June, taking the country closer to monetary union and offering the chance of another interest-rate cut sooner than many expected, analysts said on Monday.
The National Statistics Institute announced the consumer price index (CPI) fell 0.3 percent compared with May, pulling the year-on-year rise back to 1.8 percent from 2.1 percent the previous month.
"It's a good number, better than even the most optimistic forecasts," said economist Martim Amaral Neto of Banco Essi.

The drop in the CPI, after a surprising 0.7 rise in May, showed inflation was firmly on a downward path again and that the government target of a 12-month average of 2.5 percent by December should be easily achieved, analysts said.

The June decline took the rolling average -- the government's benchmark rate -- to 2.9 percent in June. Analysts say the government's target should leave Portugal comfortably within the limits for European economic and monetary union.

"The next few months may see some volatility in the year-on-year rate, but average inflation should fall to 2.7 percent in June and 2.5 percent in August," said Pedro Braz Teixeira of Banco Santander de Negocios Portugal (BSNP)
"The average inflation rate at the end of the year should be 2.2 percent," said Nuno Godinho of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
Food and beverages, accounting for nearly 45 percent of the basket of products making up the CPI, led the decline, with meat prices dropping 3.7 percent.

However, analysts said that just as important as the decline in the headline CPI figure was the progress being made in reducing rises in non-tradable goods -- basically wages -- which climbed just 4.1 percent year-on-year in June, the lowest such increase since 1974.
Some analysts said that if the non-tradable goods sector continued to perform favourably, then the Bank of Portugal might surprise the markets again with a rate cut during the summer.

The Bank cut 0.30 percent off its key rates on Friday in a move clearly anticipating the good inflation figures. The size of the move led many analysts to predict it would take no further action before the autumn.
"The year-on-year rate of increase in non-tradable goods is going to decline gradually moving towards the current level of wage rises which stands at 3.6 percent," said Braz Teixeira.
"It is possible that somebody is going to get a surprise (on their forecasts) for Bank of Portugal rate cuts because there is room for one and the CPI figure proves it," Godinho said.
Another analyst with a foreign bank said that the inflation figured showed that the Bank of Portugal ought to follow any move by Spain and, possibly, even anticipate future cuts by its neighbour.
"It could be during the summer," said the analyst who asked not to be named.
Short-term interest rates in Portugal remain above those of Spain even though many analysts see Portugal as even better placed to join the single currency in 1999.
The Bank of Portugal's repo rate stands at 5.70 percent against the Spanish central bank's 5.25 percent.

"The tendency is going to be for a convergence with Spain and the yield curve is going to steepen quite significant, I have no doubts about that," said Godinho, referring to the differential between short and longer term interest rates.
The difference in yields between the two year and the 10 year Portuguese bonds stands at 105 basis points, compared with a differential of 125 in Spain.
--Lisbon bureau 3511-3150035
